response: Sorry, I'm not sure on that one.
He had a promising future at a promising company. And he threw it all away for some short term money.
I can't respect a person who would do something like that.
An innocent girl is dead and we must now decide who is responsible.
It is a task not to be taken lightly, if one has any respect for the dead whatsoever.
During the trial, the prosecution showed us photos of the officer's from after the alleged assault. I couldn't believe the amount of blood he had on his face.
I don't think it's medically possible for someone to bleed that much just from a broken nose.
He claims he was only punched once, but he looked like he had just been attacked by a gang of animal rights activists.
This new "tough on crime" initiative spearheaded by the current administration is really having an effect on our justice system.
Between appointing that hardline attourney general and changing the rules of the criminal process to favor conviction, we may be moving towards a more authoritarian society.
All this bloodshed for a few years of salary.

His alibi was that he was at work until 7 PM, so it would have been after the murder took place. His coworker says he definitely was not there, because he would have seen his office lights on. The janitor says he might have seen him walking across the campus about 100 feet away, but he wasn't questioned until a week later so he may have not remembered correctly.
Pitting these testimonies against each other, the coworker's seems more reliable.
I vehemently despise guns. You saw the same trial I did.
I imagine all of those little metal shards shredding through my body and-
Well it's not something I particularly like to think about.

text: Uh, um. Hey everybody. Should we get started here?
Couldn't the forensic scientists tell if someone held the gun after the defendant, even if he was wearing gloves?
Wouldn't the gloves smudge the prints?
The officer certainly took a beating. But that really seemed like more blood than would be produced by a simple punch to the face, no?
It was too much blood, I think. Do you really think someone would bleed that much from a simple punch to the face?
Maybe he was cuffed with his hands behind his back?
He said during the trial that his coworker could attest to his presence at work until 7 PM. But the coworker denied this, saying he would have seen him if he had come in.
That can't be it. Who would lie about something like that just so they can be put on a project?
I just can't imagine someone being that much of an idiot.
Yes. The burden of proof is on the prosecution.
That seems plausible.
They had been together for seven years, so it's not the worst assumption.
I believe the burden of proof lies with the prosecution to prove that he bought it recently, not with the defense to prove he didn't.
Right. Thanks.
The stories provided by the defense and prosecution differ slightly.

The prosecution claims that he attacked the police officer with a punch to the nose in order to incapacitate him long enough to make an escape. But fortunately for him, another officer arrived on the scene just in time to provide assistance.
The defense denies him having attacked the officer in any way.
Something put that blood on his face, that's for sure.
I heard about her being a bit corrupt, but this completey over the line!
This trial is tainted. We have to acquit.

acquitEntirely: Weighing up the facts of the case, I think there is room for reasonable doubt.
chargeWithAssault: I believe he is not guilty of murder but guilty of assault.
completelyGuilty: I do not believe there is room for reasonable doubt in this case. He is surely guilty.
guiltyShotgun: All of the evidence puts him on the other end of that shotgun.
guiltyMotivePlusOpportunity: I think his alibi is phony and I think he had plenty of reason to kill that girl.
